content: Dried meat product from China **Meat floss**, also known as ***yuk sung*** or ***rousong*** ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 肉鬆; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *ròusōng*; [Jyutping](/wiki/Jyutping): *juk6 sung1* ; [Mandarin Chinese](/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese): [ɻôʊsʊ́ŋ]), is a dried meat product of Chinese origin, with a light and fluffy texture similar to coarse cotton. It is more commonly known as ***bak hu*** ([Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien): 肉拊, [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): bah-hú) in [Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien)-influenced regions, such as [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia) and [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan). ## Production and styles Meat floss is made by stewing finely cut [pork](/wiki/Pork), [chicken](/wiki/Chicken_as_food) or [beef](/wiki/Beef) (though other meats may be used) in a sweetened mixture of [soy sauce](/wiki/Soy_sauce) and various spices until individual [muscle](/wiki/Muscle) fibers can be easily torn apart. This happens when the water-insoluble [collagen](/wiki/Collagen) that holds the muscle fibers of the meat together has been converted into water-soluble [gelatine](/wiki/Gelatine). There are two styles of meat floss, which differ in whether oil is added during the last process of production. The [Jiangsu](/wiki/Jiangsu) style *rousong* is dry-cooked and the product is slightly chewy, while the [Fujian](/wiki/Fujian_cuisine) style *bak hu* is fried with oil and the product is mildly crispy. Five kilograms (11 lb) of meat will usually yield about one kilogram (2.2 lb) of floss. ## Variations Part of a series on[Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Chinese_cuisine)[Regional cuisines](/wiki/Chinese_regional_cuisine)Four Great Traditions - [Chuan (Sichuan)](/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine) - [Lu (Shandong)](/wiki/Shandong_cuisine) - [Yue (Guangdong)](/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine) - [Huaiyang (Jiangsu)](/wiki/Huaiyang_cuisine) Eight Great Traditions (+all above) - [Anhui](/wiki/Anhui_cuisine) - [Fujian](/wiki/Fujian_cuisine) - [Hunan](/wiki/Hunan_cuisine) - [Zhejiang](/wiki/Zhejiang_cuisine) Ten Great Traditions (+all above) - [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing_cuisine) - [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai_cuisine) Twelve Great Traditions (+all above) - [Henan](/wiki/Henan_cuisine) - [Shaanxi](/wiki/Shaanxi_cuisine) Fourteen Great Traditions (+all above) - [Hubei](/wiki/Hubei_cuisine) - [Liaoning](/wiki/Liaoning_cuisine) Sixteen Great Traditions (+all above) - [Tianjin](/wiki/Tianjin_cuisine) - [Yunnan](/wiki/Yunnan_cuisine) New Eight Great Traditions - [Gansu](/wiki/Gansu_cuisine) - [List of Chinese dishes](/wiki/List_of_Chinese_dishes) - [List of Chinese restaurants](/wiki/List_of_Chinese_restaurants) - [List of restaurants in China](/wiki/List_of_restaurants_in_China) - Asia portal - China portal - Taiwan portal - Hong Kong portal - Singapore portal - Malaysia portal - v - t - e [Fish](/wiki/Fish_as_food) can also be made into floss (魚鬆; *yú sōng*), though initial stewing is not required due to the low collagen and [elastin](/wiki/Elastin) content of fish meat. [Rabbit](/wiki/Cuniculture) and [duck](/wiki/Duck_as_food) floss can also be found in China. In Muslim-majority [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia) and [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), beef or chicken floss is the most popular variant, commonly called *abon* in [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_language) and *serunding* (also spelled *serondeng*) in [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language). In Malaysia, *serunding* is often served during [Ramadan](/wiki/Ramadan) and [Eid](/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr). ## Health effects A study has demonstrated a positive correlation between increased processing temperatures of meat floss and increased formation of [heterocyclic aromatic amines](/wiki/Heterocyclic_amine_formation_in_meat) (HAAs) within the meat. Up to seven different HAAs were found when meat floss was processed at 150 °C (302 °F). HAAs are believed to [promote the development](/wiki/Carcinogen) of some cancers. - [Bakkwa](/wiki/Bakkwa) – Salty-sweet dried meat product - [Čvarci](/wiki/%C4%8Cvarci) – Southeastern European pork rind - [Dried shredded squid](/wiki/Dried_shredded_squid) – Seafood product - [*Katsuobushi*](/wiki/Katsuobushi) – Dried, fermented, and smoked skipjack tuna - [Machaca](/wiki/Machaca) – Mexican dish - [Pemmican](/wiki/Pemmican) – Food mix with long shelf life, sometimes used as survival food - [Pulled pork](/wiki/Pulled_pork) – Pork barbecue dish of the Southern United States - [Serundeng](/wiki/Serundeng) – Indonesian spiced grated coconut - Food portal Media related to Meat floss at Wikimedia Commons
title: Meat floss
